# Introduction to Spark & Zeppelin

paragraphs.text:
%md
![Spark logo](http://spark.apache.org/images/spark-logo-trademark.png)
#
[Apache Spark](http://spark.apache.org/) is a cluster computing engine designed to be __fast__ and __general-purpose__, making it the ideal choice for processing of large datasets. It answers those two points with __efficient data sharing__ accross computations.
<hr/>
The past years have seen a major changes in computing systems, as growing data volumes required more and more applications to scale out to large clusters. To solve this problem, a wide range of new programming models have been designed to manage multiple types of computations in a distributed fashion, without having people learn too much about distributed systems. Those programming models would need to deal with _parallelism, fault-tolerance and resource sharing_ for us.

[Google's MapReduce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MapReduce) presented a simple and general model for batch processing, which handles faults and parallelism easily. Unfortunately the programming model is not adapted for other types of workloads, and multiple specialized systems were born to answer a specific need in a distributed way. 
* Iterative : Giraph
* Interactive : Impala, Piccolo, Greenplum
* Streaming : Storm, Millwheel

#
The initial goal of Apache Spark is to try and unify all of the workloads for generality purposes. [Matei Zaharia](https://cs.stanford.edu/~matei/) in his [PhD dissertation](https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Pubs/TechRpts/2014/EECS-2014-12.pdf) suggests that most of the data flow models that required a specialized system needed _efficient data sharing_ accross computations:
* Iterative algorithms like PageRank or K-Means need to make multiple passes over the same dataset
* Interactive data mining often requires running multiple ad-hoc queries on the same subset of data
* Streaming applications need to maintain and share state over time.

He then proposes to create a new abstraction that gives its users direct control over data sharing, something that other specialized systems would have built-in for their specific needs. The abstraction is implemented inside a new engine that is today called Apache Spark. The engine makes it possible to support more types of computations than with the original MapReduce in a more efficient way, including interactive queries and stream processing.

result.msg:
Apache Spark is a cluster computing engine designed to be fast and general-purpose, making it the ideal choice for processing of large datasets. It answers those two points with efficient data sharing accross computations.

The past years have seen a major changes in computing systems, as growing data volumes required more and more applications to scale out to large clusters. To solve this problem, a wide range of new programming models have been designed to manage multiple types of computations in a distributed fashion, without having people learn too much about distributed systems. Those programming models would need to deal with parallelism, fault-tolerance and resource sharing for us.

Google's MapReduce presented a simple and general model for batch processing, which handles faults and parallelism easily. Unfortunately the programming model is not adapted for other types of workloads, and multiple specialized systems were born to answer a specific need in a distributed way.

  • Iterative : Giraph
  • Interactive : Impala, Piccolo, Greenplum
  • Streaming : Storm, Millwheel

The initial goal of Apache Spark is to try and unify all of the workloads for generality purposes. Matei Zaharia in his PhD dissertation suggests that most of the data flow models that required a specialized system needed efficient data sharing accross computations:

  • Iterative algorithms like PageRank or K-Means need to make multiple passes over the same dataset
  • Interactive data mining often requires running multiple ad-hoc queries on the same subset of data
  • Streaming applications need to maintain and share state over time.

He then proposes to create a new abstraction that gives its users direct control over data sharing, something that other specialized systems would have built-in for their specific needs. The abstraction is implemented inside a new engine that is today called Apache Spark. The engine makes it possible to support more types of computations than with the original MapReduce in a more efficient way, including interactive queries and stream processing.

paragraphs.text:
%md

![](https://zeppelin.apache.org/assets/themes/zeppelin/img/zeppelin_classic_logo.png)
#
[Apache Zeppelin](https://zeppelin.apache.org/) is a web-based notebook that enables interactive data analytics. It is  famous for its very strong Apache Spark integration.
<hr/>

Apache Zeppelin's purpose is to provide engineers and scientists with an interface for all Big Data needs, which comes bundled with the means for analyzing, collaborating and sharing data on top of common Big Data frameworks.

The Apache Zeppelin interpreter concept allows the plugin of a language or data-processing backend into Zeppelin _(think of it like a kernel for Jupyter notebook)_. Currently it supports [many interpreters](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.6.2/manual/interpreterinstallation.html) like Apache Spark, Python, JDBC, Markdown and shell. Creation of a custom interpreter is also possible by extending the necessary abstract class.

You can view examples of Zeppelin notebooks [here](https://www.zeppelinhub.com/viewer).

Today, Apache Zeppelin comes bundled with most Big Data distributions _(Cloudera, Hortonworks...)_ as the main tool for interactive Big Data analytics, which makes for a good reason to have you try Apache Spark interactively in a Zeppelin notebook.

result.msg:
Apache Zeppelin is a web-based notebook that enables interactive data analytics. It is famous for its very strong Apache Spark integration.

Apache Zeppelin's purpose is to provide engineers and scientists with an interface for all Big Data needs, which comes bundled with the means for analyzing, collaborating and sharing data on top of common Big Data frameworks.

The Apache Zeppelin interpreter concept allows the plugin of a language or data-processing backend into Zeppelin (think of it like a kernel for Jupyter notebook). Currently it supports many interpreters like Apache Spark, Python, JDBC, Markdown and shell. Creation of a custom interpreter is also possible by extending the necessary abstract class.

You can view examples of Zeppelin notebooks here.

Today, Apache Zeppelin comes bundled with most Big Data distributions (Cloudera, Hortonworks…) as the main tool for interactive Big Data analytics, which makes for a good reason to have you try Apache Spark interactively in a Zeppelin notebook.

paragraphs.text:
%md ###Interpreter Apache Zeppelin is primarily a notebook. A Zeppelin notebook consists of a set of cells with an interpreter _(or language backend)_ attached. For example, this cell is linked to the Markdown interpreter, so when you run the cell it parses the code as Markdown and then displays the result. You will find the most useful markdown components [on this cheatsheet](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet). In each cell, there is a toolbar with four items: * The `Play` button (blue triangle) lets you run the paragraph. You can also press `Shift + Enter` to run the cell when selected * The `Show/Hide editor` if you want to see the source code for the cell * The `Show/Hide output` if you want to see the output for the cell * The `Settings` item, for more advanced options like adding/managing cells.

Exercise

Now you can press `Show editor` to see the source code of the cell. You will see that it starts with `%md`, which specifies to the cell that it should use the Markdown interpreter. You can edit the text and then run the cell to see the editing in the output.

result.msg:
Interpreter

Apache Zeppelin is primarily a notebook. A Zeppelin notebook consists of a set of cells with an interpreter (or language backend) attached.

For example, this cell is linked to the Markdown interpreter, so when you run the cell it parses the code as Markdown and then displays the result.

You will find the most useful markdown components on this cheatsheet.

In each cell, there is a toolbar with four items:

  • The Play button (blue triangle) lets you run the paragraph. You can also press Shift + Enter to run the cell when selected
  • The Show/Hide editor if you want to see the source code for the cell
  • The Show/Hide output if you want to see the output for the cell
  • The Settings item, for more advanced options like adding/managing cells.

Exercise

Now you can press Show editor to see the source code of the cell. You will see that it starts with %md, which specifies to the cell that it should use the Markdown interpreter. You can edit the text and then run the cell to see the editing in the output.

paragraphs.text:
%md Apache Zeppelin follows the responsive 12-column grid system. In the following row we show 3 different interpreters in action. You will find the width of the cell inside the settings button.

Exercise

You can go on and try to modify the source code in the three following cells and re-execute the code. For example, try to type `1+2` in the Python cell.

result.msg:
Apache Zeppelin follows the responsive 12-column grid system. In the following row we show 3 different interpreters in action.

You will find the width of the cell inside the settings button.

Exercise

You can go on and try to modify the source code in the three following cells and re-execute the code. For example, try to type 1+2 in the Python cell.

paragraphs.title: Shell cell
paragraphs.text:
%sh
echo "Hello Ahmadou"
echo 1+2|bc

paragraphs.title: Python cell
paragraphs.text:
%python
print("1 + 2")
print(1+2)

paragraphs.title: Spark/Scala cell
paragraphs.text:
println("Hey Guys")
println(1+2)

%md

As you can see, we have not chosen an interpreter in the last column. 

A default interpreter is set at the beginning of the notebook, on the right-hand of the menu toolbar at the top in the menu `Interpreter binding` and represented by a gear. You can also select/deselect usable interpreters for the notebook.

For more information on how each interpreter is configured, you can check the interpreter menu, in the dropdown menu with your username _(anonymous for now. Do note that Apache Zeppelin also support user authentication for multitenancy but we are not going to delve into that)_.

For now, we assume that the default interpreter is the Apache Spark/Scala interpreter, so the default cell parses Spark/Scala code. The tutorial series will be mostly using this interpreter. No Scala knowledge is needed to pursue through the series, as we will only use basic functional programming concepts.

_If you are wondering why Scala, Apache Spark is implemented in Scala, and so is its main API. Apache Spark draws from the functional paradigm for representing its computations the same way as MapReduce does. A common justification is Spark and MapReduce specialize in coarse-grained transformations that apply the same operation on many data items, which is a good fit for parallel applications, and the functional programming paradigm fits the idea._

result.msg:
As you can see, we have not chosen an interpreter in the last column.

A default interpreter is set at the beginning of the notebook, on the right-hand of the menu toolbar at the top in the menu Interpreter binding and represented by a gear. You can also select/deselect usable interpreters for the notebook.

For more information on how each interpreter is configured, you can check the interpreter menu, in the dropdown menu with your username (anonymous for now. Do note that Apache Zeppelin also support user authentication for multitenancy but we are not going to delve into that).

For now, we assume that the default interpreter is the Apache Spark/Scala interpreter, so the default cell parses Spark/Scala code. The tutorial series will be mostly using this interpreter. No Scala knowledge is needed to pursue through the series, as we will only use basic functional programming concepts.

If you are wondering why Scala, Apache Spark is implemented in Scala, and so is its main API. Apache Spark draws from the functional paradigm for representing its computations the same way as MapReduce does. A common justification is Spark and MapReduce specialize in coarse-grained transformations that apply the same operation on many data items, which is a good fit for parallel applications, and the functional programming paradigm fits the idea.

paragraphs.text:
%md ### The Spark/Scala interpreter Let's dive into the Spark/Scala interpreter now. First, we need to describe the Scala language a bit more. Scala is a functional object-oriented language. The following row shows some commands in Scala. Do note that you can use autocompletion with `Ctrl + .`

Exercise

Because you get instant feedback, you should feel encouraged to experiment, so do not hesitate to edit the Scala source code and re-execute the cell.

paragraphs.title: Some arithmetic
Declaring variables
paragraphs.text:
val a = 3 // val defines an immutable value
var b : Int = 5 // var defines a mutable variable
println(a + b)

b = 42
println(a + b)

// Note that the type of a variable or function is written after the variable or function. 

// Because Scala does type inference, it is also not necessary to declare type to variables when it looks obvious.

result.msg:
a: Int = 3

b: Int = 5
8

b: Int = 42
45

paragraphs.title: Reusing a variable
paragraphs.text:
// variables are accessible accross cells

a * b

%md

In Scala, you are encouraged to use a `val` whenever you can so to avoid mutable code. Scala prefers immutability by design and helps us reason through code only. 

It also provides is with the necessary tooling to reason with immutability in mind. In the following row we study some basic collection methods which makes useless the need for mutable lists and for loops

result.msg:
In Scala, you are encouraged to use a val whenever you can so to avoid mutable code. Scala prefers immutability by design and helps us reason through code only.

It also provides is with the necessary tooling to reason with immutability in mind. In the following row we study some basic collection methods which makes useless the need for mutable lists and for loops

paragraphs.title: Create immutable sequence of numbers
paragraphs.text: val sequenceNumbers = 1 to 100

paragraphs.title: New list with all elements doubled
paragraphs.text:
sequenceNumbers.map(x => x * 2)

sequenceNumbers.map(_ * 2)

paragraphs.title: New list with pair numbers removed
paragraphs.text:
sequenceNumbers.filter(x => x % 2 != 0)

sequenceNumbers.filter(_ % 2 != 0)

paragraphs.title: Sum all elements
paragraphs.text:
sequenceNumbers.reduce((x, y) => x + y)

sequenceNumbers.reduce(_ + _)

%md 
###Primer on functional programming
Before going further, we need to go back to functional programming (sometimes abbreviated to FP in literature).

In functional programming, we construct our programs using _pure functions_, that is a function that takes an input and produces an output without any side-effects, thus forbidding mutation.

An essential and powerful concept of FP is the ability to pass functions as arguments. For example in the row below :

result.msg:
Primer on functional programming

Before going further, we need to go back to functional programming (sometimes abbreviated to FP in literature).

In functional programming, we construct our programs using pure functions, that is a function that takes an input and produces an output without any side-effects, thus forbidding mutation.

An essential and powerful concept of FP is the ability to pass functions as arguments. For example in the row below :

paragraphs.text:
/*
 * The following function adds 2 to a number.
 */
def add2(x: Int): Int = x + 2

/* now let's pass add2 function 
 * to map,
 * a function that applies a function to each element of a  * list
 */

List(1,2,3).map(add2)

result.msg:
res43: List[Int] = List(3, 4)

res44: List[Int] = List(3, 4)

Here we have presented the first two higher order functions we are going to use in this course : map and filter. Those are called element-wise transformations in that they take in a function and applies it to each element in the collection.

We can use them to do a number of things, from fetching the website associated with each URL in our collection to just squaring numbers. Imagine this scenario :

/*
 * Parses a file with URLs and puts them into a list of Strings, each being an URL to get
 */
def loadURLs(path: String): List[String] = {
    ...some code here to return list of urls...
}

/*
 * GET request on an URL and return the body
 */
def getBody(url: String): String = {
    ...some code here to return body...
}

/*
 * Detect if body consists of an image, we don't want those
 */
def filterImage(body: String): Boolean = {
    ...some code here to detect if it's an image...
}

// code to load a list of URLs and only return those who are not images
val allURLsWithoutImages = loadURLs("/data/list_of_urls.csv").map(getBody).filter(filterImage)

paragraphs.text:
%md 
The other essential higher order function you need to learn is `reduce`, which walks a function through all the elements in a collection to produce an aggregated result. 

To do that, the function operates on two elements in the sequence, and returns a new element of the same type, which is then passed to the same function with the next element in the list.

A simple example of such a function is +, which we can use to sum all of the elements in our list.

result.msg:
The other essential higher order function you need to learn is reduce, which walks a function through all the elements in a collection to produce an aggregated result.

To do that, the function operates on two elements in the sequence, and returns a new element of the same type, which is then passed to the same function with the next element in the list.

A simple example of such a function is +, which we can use to sum all of the elements in our list.

paragraphs.text:
(1 to 1000).reduce((x,y) => x+y)
(1 to 1000).reduce(_+_)

%md
In the previous row, imagine that the sum function operates on 1 and 2 and returns 3, 

then that result is passed to the function along with the next element which is 3, and the result 6 is passed with the next element 4, and then the result 10 is passed with 5 etc...

1 --|+
2 --| 3 --|+
3 --------| 6 --| +
4 --------------| 10 --| +
5 ---------------------| 15
.etc...

Similar to `reduce` is `fold`, which takes a "zero value" in addition and passed in the initial call

result.msg:
In the previous row, imagine that the sum function operates on 1 and 2 and returns 3,

then that result is passed to the function along with the next element which is 3, and the result 6 is passed with the next element 4, and then the result 10 is passed with 5 etc…

1 –|+
2 –| 3 –|+
3 ——–| 6 –| +
4 ————–| 10 –| +
5 ———————| 15
.etc…

Similar to reduce is fold, which takes a “zero value” in addition and passed in the initial call

paragraphs.text:
%md

Exercise

Try to solve the following rows. By editing the `val output = ...` line, use `map`, `filter` and `reduce` with anonymous functions on the variable `input` to return a variable `output` that will be compared to the `expected`variable. Remember your session is interactive, it makes it easy to test intermediary values when chaining functions, example : ```scala input.map(...) // 1st execution input.map(...).filter(...) // 2nd execution input.map(...).filter(...).reduce(...) // 3rd execution ```

result.msg:
Exercise

Try to solve the following rows. By editing the val output = ... line, use map, filter and reduce with anonymous functions on the variable input to return a variable output that will be compared to the expectedvariable.

Remember your session is interactive, it makes it easy to test intermediary values when chaining functions, example :

input.map(...)                                  // 1st execution
input.map(...).filter(...)                      // 2nd execution
input.map(...).filter(...).reduce(...)          // 3rd execution

paragraphs.title: Return the list of squared numbers from 1 to 5
paragraphs.text:
val input = List(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
val output = input.map(x => x*x)

val expected = List(1, 4, 9, 16, 25)

result.msg:
input: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

output: List[Int] = List(1, 4, 9, 16, 25)

expected: List[Int] = List(1, 4, 9, 16, 25)

paragraphs.title: Return the sum of elements from 1 to 5
paragraphs.text:
val input = List(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
val output = input.reduce((x, y) => x+y)

val expected = 15

result.msg:
input: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

output: Int = 15

expected: Int = 15

paragraphs.title: Return the sum of squared pair numbers between 1 and 100
paragraphs.text:
val input = 1 to 100
val output = input.filter(x => x % 2 ==0 ).map(x => x*x).reduce((x,y) => (x+y))

val expected = 171700

paragraphs.title: Get highest number in a list with a reduce
paragraphs.text:
import util.Random.nextInt
val input = Seq.fill(10)(nextInt)
val output = input.reduce((x, y) => Math.max(x,y));

val expected = input.max

%md
### Programming with RDDs
In this chapter, we are going to introduce Spark's core abstraction for working with data in a distributed and resilient way : the <text style="color:red;">resilient distributed dataset</text>, or <text style="color:red;">RDD</text>. Under the hood, Spark automatically performs the distribution of RDDs and its processing around the cluster, so we can focus on our code and not on distributed processing problems, such as the handling of data locality or resiliency in case of node failure.

A RDD consists of a collection of elements partitioned accross the nodes of a cluster of machines that can be operated on in parallel. In Spark, work is expressed by the creation and transformation of RDDs using Spark operators.

<text style="color:red;">Note</text> : RDD is the core data structure to Spark, but the style of programming we are studying in this lesson is considered the _lowest-level API_ for Spark. The Spark community is pushing the use of Structured programming with Dataframes/Datasets instead, an optimized interface for working with structured and semi-structured data, which we will learn later. Understanding RDDs is still important because it teaches you how Spark works under the hood and will serve you to understand and optimize your application when deployed into production.

This example displays the coarse-grained processing nature of Spark, that applies the same operation to many data items. This is a good fit for many parallel applications, as they _naturally apply the same operation to multiple data items_.

result.msg:
Programming with RDDs

In this chapter, we are going to introduce Spark's core abstraction for working with data in a distributed and resilient way : the resilient distributed dataset, or RDD. Under the hood, Spark automatically performs the distribution of RDDs and its processing around the cluster, so we can focus on our code and not on distributed processing problems, such as the handling of data locality or resiliency in case of node failure.

A RDD consists of a collection of elements partitioned accross the nodes of a cluster of machines that can be operated on in parallel. In Spark, work is expressed by the creation and transformation of RDDs using Spark operators.

Note : RDD is the core data structure to Spark, but the style of programming we are studying in this lesson is considered the lowest-level API for Spark. The Spark community is pushing the use of Structured programming with Dataframes/Datasets instead, an optimized interface for working with structured and semi-structured data, which we will learn later. Understanding RDDs is still important because it teaches you how Spark works under the hood and will serve you to understand and optimize your application when deployed into production.

This example displays the coarse-grained processing nature of Spark, that applies the same operation to many data items. This is a good fit for many parallel applications, as they naturally apply the same operation to multiple data items.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Running **Spark**
The variable **sc** allows you to access a Spark Context to run your Spark programs.
* For more information about Spark, please refer to [Spark Overview](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/)

**Important note:** Do not create the *sc* variable - it is already initialized for you.

result.msg:
Running Spark

The variable sc allows you to access a Spark Context to run your Spark programs.

  • For more information about Spark, please refer to Spark Overview

Important note: Do not create the sc variable - it is already initialized for you.

paragraphs.text:
%md As you can see, the RDD API is very similar to the functions we have previously used for processing entire collections. If you already are a Scala developer, or are used to functional programming on collections, then RDDs act like a collection that Spark parallelizes on the cluster under the hood. Spark also provides us with more generic functions.

Exercise

Try to solve the following row. Browse the Spark API documentation to find the corresponding function.

result.msg:
As you can see, the RDD API is very similar to the functions we have previously used for processing entire collections.

If you already are a Scala developer, or are used to functional programming on collections, then RDDs act like a collection that Spark parallelizes on the cluster under the hood.

Spark also provides us with more generic functions.

Exercise

Try to solve the following row. Browse the Spark API documentation to find the corresponding function.

paragraphs.title: Calculate the number of unique words in the "words" RDD here.
paragraphs.text:
val words = sc.parallelize(Array("hello", "world", "goodbye", "hello", "again")).distinct.count
val expected = 4

paragraphs.title: Create a random RDD of numbers, and find its mean.
paragraphs.text:
import util.Random.nextInt
val input = sc.parallelize(Seq.fill(10000)(nextInt))
input.mean

result.msg:
import util.Random.nextInt

input: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[Int] = ParallelCollectionRDD[17] at parallelize at <console>:36

res11: Double = -5755404.093400002

paragraphs.text:
%md #### Key value pairs When doing Hadoop MapReduce, you are used to working with key-value pairs. In Scala, we use tuples to manage multiple data altogether. ```scala val t = (1, "hello", Console) ``` It is possible to access elements in a tuple : ```scala val t = (4,3,2,1) val sum = t._1 + t._2 + t._3 + t._4 ``` Now remember the reduce example, which takes 2 elements organized as tuples : ```scala (1 to 1000).reduce((x,y) => x+y) ``` You can deconstruct the tuple inside the anonymous function, it makes it easier to reason around them. This can make for some convoluted one liners. ```scala (1 to 1000) .map(x => (x, 2*x, 3*x)) .reduce{case ((x1, doubleX1, tripleX1), (x2, doubleX2, tripleX2)) => (x1 + x2, doubleX1 * doubleX2, tripleX1 - tripleX2)} ```
In Spark, a RDD of tuples of 2 elements is considered a key-value RDD. This gives us access to [a new class of functions](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#working-with-key-value-pairs). For example, the following code uses the reduceByKey operation on key-value pairs to count how many times each line of text occurs in a file. It acts like executing reduce on the array of values under the same key. ```scala val lines = sc.textFile("data.txt") val pairs = lines.map(s => (s, 1)) val counts = pairs.reduceByKey((a, b) => a + b) ```

Exercise

Try to solve the following cells.

result.msg:
Key value pairs

When doing Hadoop MapReduce, you are used to working with key-value pairs.

In Scala, we use tuples to manage multiple data altogether.

val t = (1, "hello", Console)

It is possible to access elements in a tuple :

val t = (4,3,2,1)
val sum = t._1 + t._2 + t._3 + t._4

Now remember the reduce example, which takes 2 elements organized as tuples :

(1 to 1000).reduce((x,y) => x+y)

You can deconstruct the tuple inside the anonymous function, it makes it easier to reason around them. This can make for some convoluted one liners.

(1 to 1000)
    .map(x => (x, 2*x, 3*x))
    .reduce{case ((x1, doubleX1, tripleX1), (x2, doubleX2, tripleX2)) => (x1 + x2, doubleX1 * doubleX2, tripleX1 - tripleX2)}

In Spark, a RDD of tuples of 2 elements is considered a key-value RDD. This gives us access to a new class of functions.

For example, the following code uses the reduceByKey operation on key-value pairs to count how many times each line of text occurs in a file. It acts like executing reduce on the array of values under the same key.

val lines = sc.textFile("data.txt")
val pairs = lines.map(s => (s, 1))
val counts = pairs.reduceByKey((a, b) => a + b)

Exercise

Try to solve the following cells.

paragraphs.title: Wordcount, easy mode
paragraphs.text:
val input = sc.parallelize(Seq("hi", "my", "my", "name", "is","hi"))
val output = input.flatMap(line => line.split(" ")).map(a => (a,1)).reduceByKey((a,b) => a + b).collect()

val expected = Array(("is",1), ("my,2"), ("name",1), ("hi",2))

result.msg:
input: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[String] = ParallelCollectionRDD[32] at parallelize at <console>:36

output: Array[(String, Int)] = Array((is,1), (my,2), (name,1), (hi,2))

expected: Array[java.io.Serializable] = Array((is,1), my,2, (name,1), (hi,2))

paragraphs.title: Sum ages per gender
paragraphs.text:
val rdd1 = sc.parallelize(Seq(("Patrick", "homme"), ("Sandra", "femme"), ("Faniki", "homme"), ("Noemie", "femme"), ("Francois", "homme"), ("Cassandre", "femme")))
val rdd2 = sc.parallelize(Seq(("Patrick", 20), ("Sandra", 25), ("Faniki", 20), ("Noemie", 20), ("Francois", 30), ("Cassandre", 18)))

// rdd1 and rdd2 are key-value rdds so you can join them and then continue the computation
val output = rdd1.join(rdd2).map(w => w._2).reduceByKey((w,x) => (w + x)).collect()

val expected = Array(("femme", 63), ("homme", 70))

result.msg:
rdd1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, String)] = ParallelCollectionRDD[50] at parallelize at <console>:36

rdd2: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, Int)] = ParallelCollectionRDD[51] at parallelize at <console>:36

output: Array[(String, Int)] = Array((femme,63), (homme,70))

expected: Array[(String, Int)] = Array((femme,63), (homme,70))

paragraphs.text:
%md #### To the real wordcount We are missing an important operator before going to the normal wordcount as we know it : `flatten`, which flattens the lists held inside the outer list into one resulting list. ```scala scala> val lol = List(List(1,2), List(3,4)) lol: List[List[Int]] = List(List(1, 2), List(3, 4)) scala> val result = lol.flatten result: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4) ``` In general, when reading a text, you get an array of lines like : ```scala val text = Seq( "coucou", "ceci est le cours de mapreduce", "ce n'est pas difficile", "n'est ce pas ?" ) ``` if I want the list of all the words, first I need to split each line into words and then flatten the whole : ```scala scala> val split = text.map(line => line.split(" ")) result: List[Array(String)] = List(Array("coucou"), Array("ceci", "est", "le" ...)) scala> val flat = split.flatten result: List[String] = List("coucou", "ceci", "est", "le" ...)) ``` You get the same result if you use `flatMap` : ```scala scala> val flat = text.flatMap(line => line.split(" ")) result: List[String] = List("coucou", "ceci", "est", "le" ...)) ```

Exercise

Try the wordcount on a textfile `/opt/dataset/don-quijote.txt.gz` read with Spark into a RDD ! This is it, this is the classic Hello world, it uses `flatMap` as the Hadoop Map and `reduceByKey` as the Hadoop Reduce.

result.msg:
To the real wordcount

We are missing an important operator before going to the normal wordcount as we know it : flatten, which flattens the lists held inside the outer list into one resulting list.

scala> val lol = List(List(1,2), List(3,4))
lol: List[List[Int]] = List(List(1, 2), List(3, 4))

scala> val result = lol.flatten
result: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)

In general, when reading a text, you get an array of lines like :

val text = Seq(
    "coucou",
    "ceci est le cours de mapreduce",
    "ce n'est pas difficile",
    "n'est ce pas ?"
)

if I want the list of all the words, first I need to split each line into words and then flatten the whole :

scala> val split = text.map(line => line.split(" "))
result: List[Array(String)] = List(Array("coucou"), Array("ceci", "est", "le" ...))

scala> val flat = split.flatten
result: List[String] = List("coucou", "ceci", "est", "le" ...))

You get the same result if you use flatMap :

scala> val flat = text.flatMap(line => line.split(" "))
result: List[String] = List("coucou", "ceci", "est", "le" ...))

Exercise

Try the wordcount on a textfile /opt/dataset/don-quijote.txt.gz read with Spark into a RDD ! This is it, this is the classic Hello world, it uses flatMap as the Hadoop Map and reduceByKey as the Hadoop Reduce.

text: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[String] = /opt/dataset/don-quijote.txt.gz MapPartitionsRDD[58] at textFile at <console>:38

res21: Array[String] = Array(The Project Gutenberg EBook of Don Quijote, by Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, "")

%md
### Working with **Spark SQL and DataFrames**
The variable **sqlContext** allows you to access a Spark SQL Context to work with Spark SQL and DataFrames.
* Scala can be used to create Spark [DataFrames](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html) - a distributed collection of data organized into named columns.
* DataFrames are created by appending ``.toDF()`` to the Scala RDD

In this tutorial, we will analyze the ipligence-lite csv file with SparkSQL. It is a Free IP location database solution to detect the country and continent of the visitor connection based on their IP address. [Download here if needed](http://www.ipligence.com/free-ip-database). You'll get the schema of the file there.

Before, we had to use [spark-csv](https://github.com/databricks/spark-csv) and use reflection to build Dataframes from csv files. Now spark-csv is directly integrated into Spark as a Data Source, so it is easy to parse csv files into Dataframes.

**Important note:** Do not create the *sqlContext* variable - it is already initialized for you.

// create your dataframe by reading the csv file
val columnNames = Seq("IP_FROM", "IP_TO", "COUNTRY_CODE", "COUNTRY_NAME", "CONTINENT_CODE", "CONTINENT_NAME")
val df = sqlContext.read.csv("/opt/dataset/ipligence-lite.csv").toDF(columnNames: _*)
df.printSchema()
df.show()

// if you want to use the dataframe in SQL, you must register it
df.registerTempTable("df")

%md

You have two ways to use the dataframe in SparkSQL.

1. From the SQL API of sqlContext : `sqlContext.sql("SELECT IP_TO FROM df")` see this
2. FROM the functional API : `df.select("IP_TO")`

To show the beginning of the actual dataframe, use the show() function, which is an action and so executes all of the computation.
sqlContext.sql("SELECT IP_TO FROM df").show(5)
df.select("IP_TO").show(5)

%md Because the result of those are Dataframes, you can store them in a new variable or register them for future usage. ```scala // filter with functional api val ipDf = sqlContext.sql("SELECT IP_FROM,IP_TO FROM df") ipDf.filter("IP_FROM = '0016777216'").show() // register from inside SQL API sqlContext.sql("SELECT IP_FROM,IP_TO,CONTINENT_NAME FROM df WHERE CONTINENT_NAME='ASIA'").registerTempTable("asiaOnlyDF") ```

Exercise

Solve the following queries, using one or both APIs.

paragraphs.title: Display all continent names
Count number of rows with a null value in country code
paragraphs.text: // Don't forget you have the count function on a Dataframe after you have filtered it

paragraphs.title: Display number of connections per continent
Show IP_FROM addresses which appear more than once in the file
paragraphs.text: // PS : if your query is correct, you should only find one

%md

#### Primer on Zeppelin visualization

If your dataframe is registered, you can use the %sql interpreter to directly study it. 

Normally the %sql interpreter is used to connect to a Hive metastore, the thing is a registered dataframe is actually present in the local Hive metastore so you can access it as a fake Hive table (you can see it for yourself with `sqlContext.sql("SHOW TABLES").show()`)

With the %sql interpreter, you have access to basic visualization features of Zeppelin.

paragraphs.title: If your DataFrame is stored internally, you can do some viz
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM df

paragraphs.title: You can visualize the results of a query
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT CONTINENT_NAME, COUNT(CONTINENT_NAME) as count FROM df GROUP BY CONTINENT_NAME
